text: "a market behavioural phenomena or from your superior understanding of data." Not sure I can spot the difference. Doesnt a superior understanding of data lead to value from market behavioral phenomena?

text: There are two basic approaches (and of course there are in-betweens). Approach one is where you have some data that the market doesn't - or you understand it better, approach 2 is where you just understand the behaviour of the market. If you're identifying market irrationality then you do that by looking at the market, after all everyone knows what type of race it is so if that's your data it's pretty lame.

elements.text: There are two basic approaches (and of course there are in-betweens). Approach one is where you have some data that the market doesn't - or you understand it better, approach 2 is where you just understand the behaviour of the market. If you're identifying market irrationality then you do that by looking at the market, after all everyone knows what type of race it is so if that's your data it's pretty lame.

text: Very easy to overfit if you just chop the data up lots of different ways and find one that happens to be profitable on your data set

elements.text: Very easy to overfit if you just chop the data up lots of different ways and find one that happens to be profitable on your data set

text: I would say almost impossible not to overfit - you are overfitting by definition

elements.text: I would say almost impossible not to overfit - you are overfitting by definition

text: I would start with a premise that you think might be profitable and why you think it might be profitable. Then you slice and dice your data multiple ways to check, varying parameters, over different time periods, etc. If you can't get some sort of consistency across mutually exclusive data sets then you don't have anything. Even if you do, there is no guarantee, but at least you have a good proposition

elements.text: I would start with a premise that you think might be profitable and why you think it might be profitable. Then you slice and dice your data multiple ways to check, varying parameters, over different time periods, etc. If you can't get some sort of consistency across mutually exclusive data sets then you don't have anything. Even if you do, there is no guarantee, but at least you have a good proposition

text: I'm not a big fan of a market-based approach, but I realise a stats-based approach takes a lot more effort, and many have made a market-based approach work. Maybe something hybrid, taking into account prior results, etc, is a good middle ground

text: The other thing about market irrationality is that there's no reason to try to predict it - you can just wait for it.

text: What is the difference between "market based" and "data driven"

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: What is the difference between "market based" and "data driven"

text: <@UPMUFSGCR> - data driven is where you start out with the non-market based data (prior results, statistics, etc), come up with some way to assign probabilities, or something similar, and once you have a model, then test against pricing to see if you can make it profitable. Basically testing against the market is the last step, and shouldn't influence the model, lest you overfit

elements.text: - data driven is where you start out with the non-market based data (prior results, statistics, etc), come up with some way to assign probabilities, or something similar, and once you have a model, then test against pricing to see if you can make it profitable. Basically testing against the market is the last step, and shouldn't influence the model, lest you overfit

text:
Sample size of one but I can tell you this is exactly how I got started:

1) Find a tennis model in the academic literature
2) Identify a way to improve the model
3) Implement to have probabilities independent of the market to identify value prices

End result was a highly successful strategy

text:
Thanks Misha. That is very interesting.

I suppose "data driven" approaches will tend to be more scalable than "market driven" approaches. Though market driven approaches could be more consistent. I've seen people with market driven approaches, who go for months without having a losing day. And those losing days tend to be small.

text: If you want some idea of how to map data to probabilities <@UPMUFSGCR> look into generalised linear models - particularly logistic regression for binary stuff like US sports (lack of a draw makes US sport very attractive). I started with MLB and logistic regression with data scraped off Yahoo sports. Scraping that data (and cleaning it) was by far the hardest (and most boring) component of it all.

text: A good in-between example is using GPS for horse race betting. You have a data source but it's  of middling quality and a lot of other people have it too. So to make the most of it you need a data driven model grafted onto an understanding of the very particular market dynamics of in-running horse racing. In general market driven operations will be churning vast numbers of smaller bets and outright stats models will be more likely to take fewer, bigger bets. some people make lots of money in both ways but in both cases it's not many people.

elements.text: A good in-between example is using GPS for horse race betting. You have a data source but it's  of middling quality and a lot of other people have it too. text: <@U01093Z1KF0> in general, though, it's very different. exchange trading is a bit like a simplified financial market, with the huge advantage that most of the data is openly accessible to many players. So you go fish for less informed players and take value out of them. For predicting the outcome it's different it's a pure probability game and it's one where you can't really play unless you have a sizeable bank, because the variance will hit and it may criplle your long term +EV strategy

text: If people are wondering which type of style to start with I'd suggest that the stats based approach is only most suitable if you have solid reasons to be very confident of your statistical superiority - like a relevant PHD, some relevant experience, a lot of resources and the time to wait it out. If you want to get going quickly and you're just testing the water don't go too elaborate just develop something small and market based and build it up slowly. What the very biggest players do is neither here nor there for most of us. Chances are you're not going to be the next Tony Bloom, but people like me who start out with no expertise at all sometimes make very good sums with very modest beginnings. The average Joe would see my yearly income as a life changing sum. It's less than Tony Bloom but it's more than enough for the rest of us. Whichever way you go there is masses of competition who have a huge head start on you, it can be done but it's not wise to blithely assume that that means you can do it.

text: also what you care is value, rather than accuracy, so you probably want to frame it slightly different problem. Odds per se are a prior (slightly altered bythe need of the bookie to make money). It's almost adversarial: you want to classify the situations where their model is underpredicting / overpredicting.

text: Interesting disscussion in the thread. <@U016535QCJ2> said that it would be almost impossible not to overfit. Isint it the way you find a profitable strategie? You are overfiting it to see if under your defined conditions you will be profitable. You just need to make sure that every filter/definition has enough testcases by its own. If thats the case the overfitting is not a problem.

text: high precision != overfitting. overfitting means you are not able to recognize when things are different than your assumptions. high precision means when something happens you are pretty sure something else happens. Knowing that temporal odds decay exists and is perturbed by, say, a red-card, is high precision. Thinking the odds decay and never taking into account red cards is over fitting :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: high precision != overfitting. overfitting means you are not able to recognize when things are different than your assumptions. high precision means when something happens you are pretty sure something else happens. Knowing that temporal odds decay exists and is perturbed by, say, a red-card, is high precision. Thinking the odds decay and never taking into account red cards is over fitting

text: This is an interesting thing, in the sense that the 'efficient market' hypothesis says that the market contains all the information you need because its price contains all the information, and that 50% of people will overestimate something ~ as much as 50% will underestimate it. However, I think that's simplistic. One, there's a time axis that the market requires to incorporate the information and two, people are not omniscient.

elements.text: This is an interesting thing, in the sense that the 'efficient market' hypothesis says that the market contains all the information you need because its price contains all the information, and that 50% of people will overestimate something ~ as much as 50% will underestimate it. However, I think that's simplistic. One, there's a time axis that the market requires to incorporate the information and two, people are not omniscient.

text: BF markets are not fully efficient. The existence of winners tells you that. They appear efficient when examined on mass - IE half of all bets matched at 2 do win, but that doesn't mean that all bets matched at 2 are 0EV, it just means that there are as many +EV backs at 2 are there are lays. That said, BF markets are almost efficient most of the time and assuming market efficiency is the place to start.

elements.text: BF markets are not fully efficient. The existence of winners tells you that. They appear efficient when examined on mass - IE half of all bets matched at 2 do win, but that doesn't mean that all bets matched at 2 are 0EV, it just means that there are as many +EV backs at 2 are there are lays. That said, BF markets are almost efficient most of the time and assuming market efficiency is the place to start.

text: I think this is the same with a lot of markets - if you look at equities, fx etc etc you generally find that an aggregated view of pricing suggests market efficiency. But when you start peeling back layers (looking at market microstructure, for example) you can find pockets of inneficiency to exploit.

elements.text: I think this is the same with a lot of markets - if you look at equities, fx etc etc you generally find that an aggregated view of pricing suggests market efficiency. But when you start peeling back layers (looking at market microstructure, for example) you can find pockets of inneficiency to exploit.
